00024   class GeodesicLine;
00025 
00026   /**
00027    * \brief %Geodesic calculations
00028    *
00029    * The shortest path between two points on a ellipsoid at (\e lat1, \e lon1)
00030    * and (\e lat2, \e lon2) is called the geodesic.  Its length is \e s12 and
00031    * the geodesic from point 1 to point 2 has azimuths \e azi1 and \e azi2 at
00032    * the two end points.  (The azimuth is the heading measured clockwise from
00033    * north.  \e azi2 is the "forward" azimuth, i.e., the heading that takes you
00034    * beyond point 2 not back to point 1.)
00035    *
00036    * Given \e lat1, \e lon1, \e azi1, and \e s12, we can determine \e lat2, \e
00037    * lon2, and \e azi2.  This is the \e direct geodesic problem and its
00038    * solution is given by the function Geodesic::Direct.  (If \e s12 is
00039    * sufficiently large that the geodesic wraps more than halfway around the
00040    * earth, there will be another geodesic between the points with a smaller \e
00041    * s12.)
00042    *
00043    * Given \e lat1, \e lon1, \e lat2, and \e lon2, we can determine \e azi1, \e
00044    * azi2, and \e s12.  This is the \e inverse geodesic problem, whose solution
00045    * is given by Geodesic::Inverse.  Usually, the solution to the inverse
00046    * problem is unique.  In cases where there are muliple solutions (all with
00047    * the same \e s12, of course), all the solutions can be easily generated
00048    * once a particular solution is provided.
00049    *
00050    * The standard way of specifying the direct problem is the specify the
00051    * distance \e s12 to the second point.  However it is sometimes useful
00052    * instead to specify the the arc length \e a12 (in degrees) on the auxiliary
00053    * sphere.  This is a mathematical construct used in solving the geodesic
00054    * problems.  The solution of the direct problem in this form is provide by
00055    * Geodesic::ArcDirect.  An arc length in excess of 180<sup>o</sup> indicates
00056    * that the geodesic is not a shortest path.  In addition, the arc length
00057    * between an equatorial crossing and the next extremum of latitude for a
00058    * geodesic is 90<sup>o</sup>.
00059    *
00060    * This class can also calculate several other quantities related to
00061    * geodesics.  These are:
00062    * - <i>reduced length</i>.  If we fix the first point and increase \e azi1
00063    *   by \e dazi1 (radians), the the second point is displaced \e m12 \e dazi1
00064    *   in the direction \e azi2 + 90<sup>o</sup>.  The quantity \e m12 is
00065    *   called the "reduced length" and is symmetric under interchange of the
00066    *   two points.  On a flat surface, we have \e m12 = \e s12.  The ratio \e
00067    *   s12/\e m12 gives the azimuthal scale for an azimuthal equidistant
00068    *   projection.
00069    * - <i>geodesic scale</i>.  Consider a reference geodesic and a second
00070    *   geodesic parallel to this one at point 1 and separated by a small
00071    *   distance \e dt.  The separation of the two geodesics at point 2 is \e
00072    *   M12 \e dt where \e M12 is called the "geodesic scale".  \e M21 is
00073    *   defined similarly (with the geodesics being parallel at point 2).  On a
00074    *   flat surface, we have \e M12 = \e M21 = 1.  The quantity 1/\e M12 gives
00075    *   the scale of the Cassini-Soldner projection.
00076    * - <i>area</i>.  Consider the quadrilateral bounded by the following lines:
00077    *   the geodesic from point 1 to point 2, the meridian from point 2 to the
00078    *   equator, the equator from \e lon2 to \e lon1, the meridian from the
00079    *   equator to point 1.  The area of this quadrilateral is represented by \e
00080    *   S12 with a clockwise traversal of the perimeter counting as a positive
00081    *   area and it can be used to compute the area of any simple geodesic
00082    *   polygon.
00083    *
00084    * Overloaded versions of Geodesic::Direct, Geodesic::ArcDirect, and
00085    * Geodesic::Inverse allow these quantities to be returned.  In addition
00086    * there are general functions Geodesic::GenDirect, and Geodesic::GenInverse
00087    * which allow an arbitrary set of results to be computed.
00088    *
00089    * Additional functionality if provided by the GeodesicLine class, which
00090    * allows a sequence of points along a geodesic to be computed.
00091    *
00092    * The calculations are accurate to better than 15 nm.  (See \ref geoderrors
00093    * for details.)
00094    *
00095    * For more information on geodesics see \ref geodesic.
00096    **********************************************************************/
00097 
00098   class Geodesic {
00099   private:
00100     typedef Math::real real;
00101     friend class GeodesicLine;
00102     static const int nA1 = GEOD_ORD, nC1 = GEOD_ORD, nC1p = GEOD_ORD,
00103       nA2 = GEOD_ORD, nC2 = GEOD_ORD,
00104       nA3 = GEOD_ORD, nA3x = nA3,
00105       nC3 = GEOD_ORD, nC3x = (nC3 * (nC3 - 1)) / 2,
00106       nC4 = GEOD_ORD, nC4x = (nC4 * (nC4 + 1)) / 2;
00107     static const unsigned maxit = 50;
00108

00110     void Lengths(real eps, real sig12,

00133     static real SinCosSeries(bool sinp,
00134                              real sinx, real cosx, const real c[], int n)
00135       throw();
00136     static inline real AngNormalize(real x) throw() {
00137       // Place angle in [-180, 180).  Assumes x is in [-540, 540).
00138       return x >= 180 ? x - 360 : x < -180 ? x + 360 : x;
00139     }
00140     static inline real AngRound(real x) throw() {
00141       // The makes the smallest gap in x = 1/16 - nextafter(1/16, 0) = 1/2^57
00142       // for reals = 0.7 pm on the earth if x is an angle in degrees.  (This
00143       // is about 1000 times more resolution than we get with angles around 90
00144       // degrees.)  We use this to avoid having to deal with near singular
00145       // cases when x is non-zero but tiny (e.g., 1.0e-200).
00146       const real z = real(0.0625); // 1/16
00147       volatile real y = std::abs(x);
00148       // The compiler mustn't "simplify" z - (z - y) to y
00149       y = y < z ? z - (z - y) : y;
00150       return x < 0 ? -y : y;
00151     }
00152     static inline void SinCosNorm(real& sinx, real& cosx) throw() {
00153       real r = Math::hypot(sinx, cosx);
00154       sinx /= r;
00155       cosx /= r;
00156     }
00157     // These are Maxima generated functions to provide series approximations to
00158     // the integrals for the ellipsoidal geodesic.
00159     static real A1m1f(real eps) throw();
00160     static void C1f(real eps, real c[]) throw();
00161     static void C1pf(real eps, real c[]) throw();
00162     static real A2m1f(real eps) throw();
00163     static void C2f(real eps, real c[]) throw();
00164     void A3coeff() throw();
00165     real A3f(real eps) const throw();
00166     void C3coeff() throw();
00167     void C3f(real eps, real c[]) const throw();
00168     void C4coeff() throw();
00169     void C4f(real k2, real c[]) const throw();
00170 
00171     enum captype {
00172       CAP_NONE = 0U,
00173       CAP_C1   = 1U<<0,
00174       CAP_C1p  = 1U<<1,
00175       CAP_C2   = 1U<<2,
00176       CAP_C3   = 1U<<3,
00177       CAP_C4   = 1U<<4,
00178       CAP_ALL  = 0x1FU,
00179       OUT_ALL  = 0x7F80U,
00180     };
00181   public:
00182 
00183     /**
00184      * Bit masks for what calculations to do.  These masks do double duty.
00185      * They signify to the GeodesicLine::GeodesicLine constructor and to
00186      * Geodesic::Line what capabilities should be included in the GeodesicLine
00187      * object.  They also specify which results to return in the general
00188      * routines Geodesic::GenDirect and Geodesic::GenInverse routines.
00189      * GeodesicLine::mask is a duplication of this enum.
00190      **********************************************************************/
00191     enum mask {
00192       /**
00193        * No capabilities, no output.
00194        * @hideinitializer
00195        **********************************************************************/
00196       NONE          = 0U,
00197       /**
00198        * Calculate latitude \e lat2.  (It's not necessary to include this as a
00199        * capability to GeodesicLine because this is included by default.)
00200        * @hideinitializer
00201        **********************************************************************/
00202       LATITUDE      = 1U<<7  | CAP_NONE,
00203       /**
00204        * Calculate longitude \e lon2.
00205        * @hideinitializer
00206        **********************************************************************/
00207       LONGITUDE     = 1U<<8  | CAP_C3,
00208       /**
00209        * Calculate azimuths \e azi1 and \e azi2.  (It's not necessary to
00210        * include this as a capability to GeodesicLine because this is included
00211        * by default.)
00212        * @hideinitializer
00213        **********************************************************************/
00214       AZIMUTH       = 1U<<9  | CAP_NONE,
00215       /**
00216        * Calculate distance \e s12.
00217        * @hideinitializer
00218        **********************************************************************/
00219       DISTANCE      = 1U<<10 | CAP_C1,
00220       /**
00221        * Allow distance \e s12 to be used as input in the direct geodesic
00222        * problem.
00223        * @hideinitializer
00224        **********************************************************************/
00225       DISTANCE_IN   = 1U<<11 | CAP_C1 | CAP_C1p,
00226       /**
00227        * Calculate reduced length \e m12.
00228        * @hideinitializer
00229        **********************************************************************/
00230       REDUCEDLENGTH = 1U<<12 | CAP_C1 | CAP_C2,
00231       /**
00232        * Calculate geodesic scales \e M12 and \e M21.
00233        * @hideinitializer
00234        **********************************************************************/
00235       GEODESICSCALE = 1U<<13 | CAP_C1 | CAP_C2,
00236       /**
00237        * Calculate area \e S12.
00238        * @hideinitializer
00239        **********************************************************************/
00240       AREA          = 1U<<14 | CAP_C4,
00241       /**
00242        * All capabilities.  Calculate everything.
00243        * @hideinitializer
00244        **********************************************************************/
00245       ALL           = OUT_ALL| CAP_ALL,
00246     };
00247 
00248     /** \name Constructor
00249      **********************************************************************/
00250     ///@{
00251     /**
00252      * Constructor for a ellipsoid with
00253      *
00254      * @param[in] a equatorial radius (meters)
00255      * @param[in] r reciprocal flattening.  Setting \e r = 0 implies \e r = inf
00256      *   or flattening = 0 (i.e., a sphere).  Negative \e r indicates a prolate
00257      *   ellipsoid.
00258      *
00259      * An exception is thrown if either of the axes of the ellipsoid is
00260      * non-positive.
00261      **********************************************************************/
00262     Geodesic(real a, real r);
00263     ///@}
00264 
00265     /** \name Direct geodesic problem specified in terms of distance.
00266      **********************************************************************/
00267     ///@{
00268     /**
00269      * Perform the direct geodesic calculation where the length of the geodesic
00270      * is specify in terms of distance.
00271      *
00272      * @param[in] lat1 latitude of point 1 (degrees).
00273      * @param[in] lon1 longitude of point 1 (degrees).
00274      * @param[in] azi1 azimuth at point 1 (degrees).
00275      * @param[in] s12 distance between point 1 and point 2 (meters); it can be
00276      *   signed.
00277      * @param[out] lat2 latitude of point 2 (degrees).
00278      * @param[out] lon2 longitude of point 2 (degrees).
00279      * @param[out] azi2 (forward) azimuth at point 2 (degrees).
00280      * @param[out] m12 reduced length of geodesic (meters).
00281      * @param[out] M12 geodesic scale of point 2 relative to point 1
00282      *   (dimensionless).
00283      * @param[out] M21 geodesic scale of point 1 relative to point 2
00284      *   (dimensionless).
00285      * @param[out] S12 area under the geodesic (meters<sup>2</sup>).
00286      * @return \e a12 arc length of between point 1 and point 2 (degrees).
00287      *
00288      * If either point is at a pole, the azimuth is defined by keeping the
00289      * longitude fixed and writing \e lat = 90 - \e eps or -90 + \e eps and
00290      * taking the limit \e eps -> 0 from above.  An arc length greater that 180
00291      * degrees signifies a geodesic which is not a shortest path.  (For a
00292      * prolate ellipsoid, an additional condition is necessary for a shortest
00293      * path: the longitudinal extent must not exceed of 180 degrees.)
00294      *
00295      * The following functions are overloaded versions of Geodesic::Direct
00296      * which omit some of the output parameters.  Note, however, that the arc
00297      * length is always computed and returned as the function value.
00298      **********************************************************************/
00299     Math::real Direct(real lat1, real lon1, real azi1, real s12,
00300                       real& lat2, real& lon2, real& azi2,
00301                       real& m12, real& M12, real& M21, real& S12)
00302       const throw() {
00303       real t;
00304       return GenDirect(lat1, lon1, azi1, false, s12,
00305                        LATITUDE | LONGITUDE | AZIMUTH |
00306                        REDUCEDLENGTH | GEODESICSCALE | AREA,
00307                        lat2, lon2, azi2, t, m12, M12, M21, S12);
00308     }
00309 
00310     /**
00311      * See the documentation for Geodesic::Direct.
00312      **********************************************************************/
00313     Math::real Direct(real lat1, real lon1, real azi1, real s12,
00314                       real& lat2, real& lon2)
00315       const throw() {
00316       real t;
00317       return GenDirect(lat1, lon1, azi1, false, s12,
00318                        LATITUDE | LONGITUDE,
00319                        lat2, lon2, t, t, t, t, t, t);
00320     }
00321

00326                       real& lat2, real& lon2, real& azi2)
00327       const throw() {
00328       real t;
00329       return GenDirect(lat1, lon1, azi1, false, s12,
00330                        LATITUDE | LONGITUDE | AZIMUTH,
00331                        lat2, lon2, azi2, t, t, t, t, t);
00332     }

00338                       real& lat2, real& lon2, real& azi2, real& m12)
00339       const throw() {
00340       real t;
00341       return GenDirect(lat1, lon1, azi1, false, s12,
00342                        LATITUDE | LONGITUDE | AZIMUTH | REDUCEDLENGTH,
00343                        lat2, lon2, azi2, t, m12, t, t, t);

00347      * See the documentation for Geodesic::Direct.

00349     Math::real Direct(real lat1, real lon1, real azi1, real s12,

00351                       real& M12, real& M21)
00352       const throw() {

00374     /** \name Direct geodesic problem specified in terms of arc length.
00375      **********************************************************************/
00376     ///@{
00377     /**
00378      * Perform the direct geodesic calculation where the length of the geodesic
00379      * is specify in terms of arc length.
00380      *
00381      * @param[in] lat1 latitude of point 1 (degrees).
00382      * @param[in] lon1 longitude of point 1 (degrees).
00383      * @param[in] azi1 azimuth at point 1 (degrees).
00384      * @param[in] a12 arc length between point 1 and point 2 (degrees); it can
00385      *   be signed.
00386      * @param[out] lat2 latitude of point 2 (degrees).
00387      * @param[out] lon2 longitude of point 2 (degrees).
00388      * @param[out] azi2 (forward) azimuth at point 2 (degrees).
00389      * @param[out] s12 distance between point 1 and point 2 (meters).
00390      * @param[out] m12 reduced length of geodesic (meters).
00391      * @param[out] M12 geodesic scale of point 2 relative to point 1
00392      *   (dimensionless).
00393      * @param[out] M21 geodesic scale of point 1 relative to point 2
00394      *   (dimensionless).
00395      * @param[out] S12 area under the geodesic (meters<sup>2</sup>).
00396      *
00397      * If either point is at a pole, the azimuth is defined by keeping the
00398      * longitude fixed and writing \e lat = 90 - \e eps or -90 + \e eps and
00399      * taking the limit \e eps -> 0 from above.  An arc length greater that 180
00400      * degrees signifies a geodesic which is not a shortest path.  (For a
00401      * prolate ellipsoid, an additional condition is necessary for a shortest
00402      * path: the longitudinal extent must not exceed of 180 degrees.)
00403      *
00404      * The following functions are overloaded versions of Geodesic::Direct
00405      * which omit some of the output parameters.
00406      **********************************************************************/
00407     void ArcDirect(real lat1, real lon1, real azi1, real a12,
00408                    real& lat2, real& lon2, real& azi2, real& s12,
00409                    real& m12, real& M12, real& M21, real& S12)
00410       const throw() {
00411       GenDirect(lat1, lon1, azi1, true, a12,
00412                 LATITUDE | LONGITUDE | AZIMUTH | DISTANCE |
00413                 REDUCEDLENGTH | GEODESICSCALE | AREA,
00414                 lat2, lon2, azi2, s12, m12, M12, M21, S12);
00415     }
00416 
00417     /**
00418      * See the documentation for Geodesic::ArcDirect.
00419      **********************************************************************/
00420     void ArcDirect(real lat1, real lon1, real azi1, real a12,
00421                    real& lat2, real& lon2) const throw() {
00422       real t;
00423       GenDirect(lat1, lon1, azi1, true, a12,
00424                 LATITUDE | LONGITUDE,
00425                 lat2, lon2, t, t, t, t, t, t);
00426     }

00489     ///@}
00490 
00491     /** \name General version of the direct geodesic solution.
00492      **********************************************************************/
00493     ///@{
00494 
00495     /**
00496      * The general direct geodesic calculation.  Geodesic::Direct and
00497      * Geodesic::ArcDirect are defined in terms of this function.
00498      *
00499      * @param[in] lat1 latitude of point 1 (degrees).
00500      * @param[in] lon1 longitude of point 1 (degrees).
00501      * @param[in] azi1 azimuth at point 1 (degrees).
00502      * @param[in] arcmode boolean flag determining the meaning of the second
00503      *   parameter.
00504      * @param[in] s12_a12 if \e arcmode is false, this is the distance between
00505      *   point 1 and point 2 (meters); otherwise it is the arc length between
00506      *   point 1 and point 2 (degrees); it can be signed.
00507      * @param[in] outmask a bitor'ed combination of Geodesic::mask values
00508      *   specifying which of the following parameters should be set.
00509      * @param[out] lat2 latitude of point 2 (degrees).
00510      * @param[out] lon2 longitude of point 2 (degrees).
00511      * @param[out] azi2 (forward) azimuth at point 2 (degrees).
00512      * @param[out] s12 distance between point 1 and point 2 (meters).
00513      * @param[out] m12 reduced length of geodesic (meters).
00514      * @param[out] M12 geodesic scale of point 2 relative to point 1
00515      *   (dimensionless).
00516      * @param[out] M21 geodesic scale of point 1 relative to point 2
00517      *   (dimensionless).
00518      * @param[out] S12 area under the geodesic (meters<sup>2</sup>).
00519      * @return \e a12 arc length of between point 1 and point 2 (degrees).
00520      *
00521      * The Geodesic::mask values possible for \e outmask are
00522      * - \e outmask |= Geodesic::LATITUDE for the latitude \e lat2.
00523      * - \e outmask |= Geodesic::LONGITUDE for the latitude \e lon2.
00524      * - \e outmask |= Geodesic::AZIMUTH for the latitude \e azi2.
00525      * - \e outmask |= Geodesic::DISTANCE for the distance \e s12.
00526      * - \e outmask |= Geodesic::REDUCEDLENGTH for the reduced length \e
00527      *   m12.
00528      * - \e outmask |= Geodesic::GEODESICSCALE for the geodesic scales \e
00529      *   M12 and \e M21.
00530      * - \e outmask |= Geodesic::AREA for the area \e S12.
00531      * .
00532      * The function value \e a12 is always computed and returned and this
00533      * equals \e s12_a12 is \e arcmode is true.  If \e outmask includes
00534      * Geodesic::DISTANCE and \e arcmode is false, then \e s12 = \e s12_a12.
00535      * It is not necessary to include Geodesic::DISTANCE_IN in \e outmask; this
00536      * is automatically included is \e arcmode is false.
00537      **********************************************************************/
00538     Math::real GenDirect(real lat1, real lon1, real azi1,
00539                          bool arcmode, real s12_a12, unsigned outmask,
00540                          real& lat2, real& lon2, real& azi2,
00541                          real& s12, real& m12, real& M12, real& M21,
00542                          real& S12) const throw();
00543     ///@}
00544 
00545     /** \name Inverse geodesic problem.
00546      **********************************************************************/
00547     ///@{
00548     /**
00549      * Perform the inverse geodesic calculation.
00550      *
00551      * @param[in] lat1 latitude of point 1 (degrees).
00552      * @param[in] lon1 longitude of point 1 (degrees).
00553      * @param[in] lat2 latitude of point 2 (degrees).
00554      * @param[in] lon2 longitude of point 2 (degrees).
00555      * @param[out] s12 distance between point 1 and point 2 (meters).
00556      * @param[out] azi1 azimuth at point 1 (degrees).
00557      * @param[out] azi2 (forward) azimuth at point 1 (degrees).
00558      * @param[out] m12 reduced length of geodesic (meters).
00559      * @param[out] M12 geodesic scale of point 2 relative to point 1
00560      *   (dimensionless).
00561      * @param[out] M21 geodesic scale of point 1 relative to point 2
00562      *   (dimensionless).
00563      * @param[out] S12 area under the geodesic (meters<sup>2</sup>).
00564      * @return \e a12 arc length of between point 1 and point 2 (degrees).
00565      *
00566      * If either point is at a pole, the azimuth is defined by keeping the
00567      * longitude fixed and writing \e lat = 90 - \e eps or -90 + \e eps and
00568      * taking the limit \e eps -> 0 from above.  If the routine fails to
00569      * converge, then all the requested outputs are set to Math::NaN().  This
00570      * is not expected to happen with ellipsoidal models of the earth; please
00571      * report all cases where this occurs.
00572      *
00573      * The following functions are overloaded versions of Geodesic::Inverse
00574      * which omit some of the output parameters.  Note, however, that the arc
00575      * length is always computed and returned as the function value.
00576      **********************************************************************/
00577     Math::real Inverse(real lat1, real lon1, real lat2, real lon2,
00578                        real& s12, real& azi1, real& azi2, real& m12,
00579                        real& M12, real& M21, real& S12) const throw() {
00580       return GenInverse(lat1, lon1, lat2, lon2,
00581                         DISTANCE | AZIMUTH |
00582                         REDUCEDLENGTH | GEODESICSCALE | AREA,
00583                         s12, azi1, azi2, m12, M12, M21, S12);
00584     }
00585 
00586     /**
00587      * See the documentation for Geodesic::Inverse.
00588      **********************************************************************/
00589     Math::real Inverse(real lat1, real lon1, real lat2, real lon2,
00590                        real& s12) const throw() {
00591       real t;
00592       return GenInverse(lat1, lon1, lat2, lon2,
00593                         DISTANCE,
00594                         s12, t, t, t, t, t, t);
00595     }
00596 
00597     /**
00598      * See the documentation for Geodesic::Inverse.
00599      **********************************************************************/
00600     Math::real Inverse(real lat1, real lon1, real lat2, real lon2,
00601                        real& azi1, real& azi2) const throw() {
00602       real t;
00603       return GenInverse(lat1, lon1, lat2, lon2,
00604                         AZIMUTH,
00605                         t, azi1, azi2, t, t, t, t);
00606     }
00607 
00608     /**
00609      * See the documentation for Geodesic::Inverse.
00610      **********************************************************************/
00611     Math::real Inverse(real lat1, real lon1, real lat2, real lon2,
00612                        real& s12, real& azi1, real& azi2)
00613       const throw() {
00614       real t;
00615       return GenInverse(lat1, lon1, lat2, lon2,
00616                         DISTANCE | AZIMUTH,
00617                         s12, azi1, azi2, t, t, t, t);
00618     }
00619 
00620     /**
00621      * See the documentation for Geodesic::Inverse.
00622      **********************************************************************/
00623     Math::real Inverse(real lat1, real lon1, real lat2, real lon2,
00624                        real& s12, real& azi1, real& azi2, real& m12)
00625       const throw() {
00626       real t;
00627       return GenInverse(lat1, lon1, lat2, lon2,
00628                         DISTANCE | AZIMUTH | REDUCEDLENGTH,
00629                         s12, azi1, azi2, m12, t, t, t);
00630     }
00631 
00632     /**
00633      * See the documentation for Geodesic::Inverse.
00634      **********************************************************************/
00635     Math::real Inverse(real lat1, real lon1, real lat2, real lon2,
00636                        real& s12, real& azi1, real& azi2,
00637                        real& M12, real& M21) const throw() {
00638       real t;
00639       return GenInverse(lat1, lon1, lat2, lon2,
00640                         DISTANCE | AZIMUTH | GEODESICSCALE,
00641                         s12, azi1, azi2, t, M12, M21, t);
00642     }
00643 
00644     /**
00645      * See the documentation for Geodesic::Inverse.
00646      **********************************************************************/
00647     Math::real Inverse(real lat1, real lon1, real lat2, real lon2,
00648                        real& s12, real& azi1, real& azi2, real& m12,
00649                        real& M12, real& M21) const throw() {
00650       real t;
00651       return GenInverse(lat1, lon1, lat2, lon2,
00652                         DISTANCE | AZIMUTH |
00653                         REDUCEDLENGTH | GEODESICSCALE,
00654                         s12, azi1, azi2, m12, M12, M21, t);
00655     }
00656     ///@}
00657 
00658     /** \name General version of inverse geodesic solution.
00659      **********************************************************************/
00660     ///@{
00661     /**
00662      * The general inverse geodesic calculation.  Geodesic::Inverse is defined
00663      * in terms of this function.
00664      *
00665      * @param[in] lat1 latitude of point 1 (degrees).
00666      * @param[in] lon1 longitude of point 1 (degrees).
00667      * @param[in] lat2 latitude of point 2 (degrees).
00668      * @param[in] lon2 longitude of point 2 (degrees).
00669      * @param[in] outmask a bitor'ed combination of Geodesic::mask values
00670      *   specifying which of the following parameters should be set.
00671      * @param[out] s12 distance between point 1 and point 2 (meters).
00672      * @param[out] azi1 azimuth at point 1 (degrees).
00673      * @param[out] azi2 (forward) azimuth at point 1 (degrees).
00674      * @param[out] m12 reduced length of geodesic (meters).
00675      * @param[out] M12 geodesic scale of point 2 relative to point 1
00676      *   (dimensionless).
00677      * @param[out] M21 geodesic scale of point 1 relative to point 2
00678      *   (dimensionless).
00679      * @param[out] S12 area under the geodesic (meters<sup>2</sup>).
00680      * @return \e a12 arc length of between point 1 and point 2 (degrees).
00681      *
00682      * The Geodesic::mask values possible for \e outmask are
00683      * - \e outmask |= Geodesic::DISTANCE for the distance \e s12.
00684      * - \e outmask |= Geodesic::AZIMUTH for the latitude \e azi2.
00685      * - \e outmask |= Geodesic::REDUCEDLENGTH for the reduced length \e
00686      *   m12.
00687      * - \e outmask |= Geodesic::GEODESICSCALE for the geodesic scales \e
00688      *   M12 and \e M21.
00689      * - \e outmask |= Geodesic::AREA for the area \e S12.
00690      * .
00691      * The arc length is always computed and returned as the function value.
00692      **********************************************************************/
00693     Math::real GenInverse(real lat1, real lon1, real lat2, real lon2,
00694                        unsigned outmask,
00695                        real& s12, real& azi1, real& azi2,
00696                        real& m12, real& M12, real& M21, real& S12)
00697       const throw();
00698     ///@}
00699 
00700     /** \name Interface to GeodesicLine.
00701      **********************************************************************/
00702     ///@{
00703 
00704     /**
00705      * Set up to do a series of ranges.
00706      *
00707      * @param[in] lat1 latitude of point 1 (degrees).
00708      * @param[in] lon1 longitude of point 1 (degrees).
00709      * @param[in] azi1 azimuth at point 1 (degrees).
00710      * @param[in] caps bitor'ed combination of Geodesic::mask values
00711      *   specifying the capabilities the GeodesicLine object should possess,
00712      *   i.e., which quantities can be returned in calls to
00713      *   GeodesicLib::Position.
00714      *
00715      * The Geodesic::mask values are
00716      * - \e caps |= Geodesic::LATITUDE for the latitude \e lat2; this is
00717      *   added automatically
00718      * - \e caps |= Geodesic::LONGITUDE for the latitude \e lon2
00719      * - \e caps |= Geodesic::AZIMUTH for the latitude \e azi2; this is
00720      *   added automatically
00721      * - \e caps |= Geodesic::DISTANCE for the distance \e s12
00722      * - \e caps |= Geodesic::REDUCEDLENGTH for the reduced length \e m12
00723      * - \e caps |= Geodesic::GEODESICSCALE for the geodesic scales \e M12
00724      *   and \e M21
00725      * - \e caps |= Geodesic::AREA for the area \e S12
00726      * - \e caps |= Geodesic::DISTANCE_IN permits the length of the
00727      *   geodesic to be given in terms of \e s12; without this capability the
00728      *   length can only be specified in terms of arc length.
00729      * .
00730      * The default value of \e caps is Geodesic::ALL which turns on all the
00731      * capabilities.
00732      *
00733      * If the point is at a pole, the azimuth is defined by keeping the \e lon1
00734      * fixed and writing \e lat1 = 90 - \e eps or -90 + \e eps and taking the
00735      * limit \e eps -> 0 from above.
00736      **********************************************************************/
00737     GeodesicLine Line(real lat1, real lon1, real azi1, unsigned caps = ALL)
00738       const throw();
00739 
00740     ///@}
00741 
00742     /** \name Inspector functions.
00743      **********************************************************************/
00744     ///@{
00745 
00746     /**
00747      * @return \e a the equatorial radius of the ellipsoid (meters).  This is
00748      *   the value used in the constructor.
00749      **********************************************************************/
00750     Math::real MajorRadius() const throw() { return _a; }
00751 
00752     /**
00753      * @return \e r the inverse flattening of the ellipsoid.  This is the
00754      *   value used in the constructor.  A value of 0 is returned for a sphere
00755      *   (infinite inverse flattening).
00756      **********************************************************************/
00757     Math::real InverseFlattening() const throw() { return _r; }
00758 
00759     /**
00760      * @return total area of ellipsoid in meters<sup>2</sup>.  The area of a
00761      *   polygon encircling a pole can be found by adding
00762      *   Geodesic::EllipsoidArea()/2 to the sum of \e S12 for each side of the
00763      *   polygon.
00764      **********************************************************************/
00765     Math::real EllipsoidArea() const throw() { return 4 * Math::pi() * _c2; }
00766     ///@}

00768     /**
00769      * A global instantiation of Geodesic with the parameters for the WGS84
00770      * ellipsoid.
00771      **********************************************************************/
00772     static const Geodesic WGS84;

00774 
00775     /** \name Deprecated function.
00776      **********************************************************************/
00777     ///@{
00778     /**
00779      * <b>DEPRECATED</b> Perform the direct geodesic calculation.  Given a
00780      * latitude, \e lat1, longitude, \e lon1, and azimuth \e azi1 (degrees) for
00781      * point 1 and a range, \e s12 (meters) from point 1 to point 2, return the
00782      * latitude, \e lat2, longitude, \e lon2, and forward azimuth, \e azi2
00783      * (degrees) for point 2 and the reduced length \e m12 (meters).  If either
00784      * point is at a pole, the azimuth is defined by keeping the longitude
00785      * fixed and writing \e lat = 90 - \e eps or -90 + \e eps and taking the
00786      * limit \e eps -> 0 from above.  If \e arcmode (default false) is set to
00787      * true, \e s12 is interpreted as the arc length \e a12 (degrees) on the
00788      * auxiliary sphere.  An arc length greater that 180 degrees results in a
00789      * geodesic which is not a shortest path.  For a prolate ellipsoid, an
00790      * additional condition is necessary for a shortest path: the longitudinal
00791      * extent must not exceed of 180 degrees.  Returned value is the arc length
00792      * \e a12 (degrees) if \e arcmode is false, otherwise it is the distance \e
00793      * s12 (meters).
00794      **********************************************************************/
00795     Math::real Direct(real lat1, real lon1, real azi1, real s12_a12,
00796                       real& lat2, real& lon2, real& azi2, real& m12,
00797                       bool arcmode) const throw() {
00798       if (arcmode) {
00799         real a12 = s12_a12, s12;
00800         ArcDirect(lat1, lon1, azi1, a12, lat2, lon2, azi2, s12, m12);
00801         return s12;
00802       } else {
00803         real s12 = s12_a12;
00804         return Direct(lat1, lon1, azi1, s12, lat2, lon2, azi2, m12);
00805       }
00806     }
00807     ///@}
00808   };
